Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from my stepmom just as I was about to log into the weekly team meeting. She and Dad expected me to check in every day, to share how work was going, what I’d eaten, even the little things like the weather outside my window. It was our way of staying close, especially since I moved out. I glanced at the clock—if I called her now, I’d miss the start of the meeting, but if I waited, she’d worry or think I was pulling away. 

At work, my manager always emphasized the importance of being present in meetings, even if they were recorded. “Participation matters,” she’d said last week, “it shows you’re engaged.” I knew my absence would be noticed, even if I watched the recording later. My phone buzzed again—“Everything okay?” My heart pounded as I stared at the screen, torn between the warmth of family and the expectations of my team. I could feel the pressure mounting, knowing that whichever choice I made, I’d be letting someone down.
